grantNo.agency: Alberta Innovates - Health Solutions (AIHS); Alberta Health Services; Alberta Children's Hospital Foundation

distrbtr.affiliation: Alberta Centre for Child, Family and Community Research

useStmt.restrctn: Author determines access on a case-by-case basis
useStmt.conditions: Access is permitted for external researchers, with limitations
useStmt.restrctn: Year 3 data (Q6M, Q6ASQ, Q6CDI) are under embargo until further notice
useStmt.conditions: Availability of the data is subject to approval after application to SAGE (see website, under Data Access). All data access requests are reviewed by the SAGE Access Review Roster, consisting of a member of the original research team, a member of the CDCA and an external reviewer. Approved requests are formalized into a Data Access Agreement, and the data are made available in the SAGE virtual research environment (VRE) to the data accessor.

setAvail.avlStatus: Restricted: Data may be available but requires the user to request permission before access can be granted.

stdyInfo.abstract: The All Our Babies (AOB) study is a prospective community-based pregnancy cohort that follows maternal-infant pairs across the early life course to describes the mental health and psychosocial characteristics of mothers living in Calgary and area, as well as estimating rates of low birth weight, small for gestational age and preterm births. This study is intended to help understand women's prenatal care experiences in Calgary and identify barriers and facilitators to accessing care. AOB data covers subject areas including: a) Maternal Prenatal Health (e.g., prenatal care, maternal gestation); b) Pregnancy History (e.g., previous pregnancies, previous preterm birth); c) Pre-pregnancy (e.g., pregnancy planning advice received, contraception use, pregnancy intention); d) Health Care Services (e.g., utilization of services for mother and baby); e) Food, Exercise and Housing (e.g., nutrition, housing, neighbourhood safety and cohesion); f) Lifestyle (e.g., T-ACE Screen for alcohol consumption risk, smoking, drugs); g) Social Support (Medical Outcomes Study Social Support Scale, partner/relationship satisfaction); h) Mental Health (e.g., Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale, Spielberger State Anxiety Scale, Perceived Stress Scale, optimism [Life Orientation Test-Revised]); i) Life Events (e.g., previous mental health, abuse); j) Sociodemographic Outcomes (e.g., age, marital status, education, ethnicity, work status); k) Birth Outcomes - maternal and delivery (e.g. site of birth, delivery type, medication, delivery support); l) Birth Outcomes -infant (e.g., sex, birth weight, gestational age); m) Baby Health/Development (e.g., doctor, check-up, vaccinations); n) Parenting/ Postpartum Experiences (e.g. Parenting Morale Index, breastfeeding [Montreal Children's Hospital Feeding Scale], community service utilization)

sumDscr.universe: Women able to communicate in written and spoken English, less than 25 weeks pregnant at enrollment, and accessing prenatal care in Calgary in 2008 or 2009.

dataColl.sampProc: No sampling procedure used. Sample acquired in 2008 - 2010 through: 1) recruitment from health care offices (posters, word-of-mouth) and the regional health services website, and 2) recruitment over the phone (Women receiving prenatal viral serology tests were contacted by Calgary Laboratory Services to request permission to release patient contact information to the AOB research staff, who if consenting were contacted to determine eligibility).
dataColl.cleanOps: The AOB team removed duplicate participant data (same mother/same child - there are some instances of same mother/different child); checked values for consistency; checked illogical values against original hard copies; and removed identifying data
